data.title: Unable to run grep in shell task
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Reproduces without extensions: Yes

## Steps to Reproduce:

I made a `task.json` in my project's workspace. Apparently there is a problem with the way command arguments are being parsed.

1. make the following `task.json` in `.vscode` directory in the workspace.

```js
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "myTask",
            "command": "grep \"HELLO\" \"${file}\"",
            "type": "shell",
            "group": {
                "kind": "build",
                "isDefault": true
            }
        }
    ]
}
```
2. Since this is the default task now, hit `CTRL+SHIFT+B`

## Output
```
> Executing task: grep "HELLO" "c:\Users\rteshnizi\project\.vscode\tasks.json" <

Usage: grep [OPTION]... PATTERN [FILE]...
Try 'grep --help' for more information.

Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.
```
## Expected Behavior
Output from Git Bash in vscode terminal
```
            "command": "grep \"HELLO\" \"${file}\"",
warning: LF will be replaced by CRLF in .vscode/settings.json.
The file will have its original line endings in your working directory.
```
Output from cmd in vscode terminal
```
            "command": "grep \"HELLO\" \"${file}\"",
```

data.title: VSCode could list multiple projects on Explorer
data.body:
Hi

Would be nice if VSCode could list multiple projects in Explorer but making it able to open just a single one as workspace.

I hope this feature could be developed in the future.

data.title: Emmet snippets -> to the TOP of snippets list
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: win7x64

Well, now "Tab" and it's double-action for tabing and Emmet expand cannot do it anymore, as I see.
So, what about setting, that will put Emmet snippets **TO THE TOP**  of the common snippets list?

We have nice setting called **"editor.snippetSuggestions"** and one of its value called **"top"**
But it works only for snippets, written in "[language].json" files.

So, what about Emmet snippets? It also should have settings like this!

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29227489-ad8802f4-7ede-11e7-86ae-771de6c67163.png)

data.title: [Feature Request] editor.links should be true, false or hover
data.body:
```
// Controls whether the editor should detect links and make them clickable
"editor.links": true,
```

Amazing feature, but it's bad when we have interpolation in urls.
This setting should be a three-state setting: true for showing links and make them clickable, false for turn off and "hover" for link and clickable only if mouse is on top of it (so it doesn't interfere with interpolation)

data.title: [Feature Request] Cloud settings
data.body:
I know that there is gist settings saver, but is so confusing...

It would be nice if we could link Visual Studio Code settings with OneDrive, GoogleDrive, etc. or even with some online service running on Azure with our Live account.

Visual Studio Code would have to implement diff and keep things in check (I do this in Visual Studio "normal", saving my settings on my OneDrive folder, but it cannot handle conflicts by itself and generates a lot of conflicted copies of those configuration files =\)

data.title: [Feature Request] Visual Studio formatters
data.body:
There is a lot of conflicting formatters in the market place and none of them format code as I like (Visual Studio does): expanded { on CSS and JavaScript, XML, JSON (expanded {), etc.

It would be nice a package with the same formatters found in Visual Studio (as they are perfect), and one for each language (because today when I need a JS formatter, I get a JS and a CSS formater, but another plugin formats CSS better than the first one, so I end up with not optimal choices or more than one formatter installed).

data.title: Improve "uninstall first" messaging/grammar
data.body:
See #29537

Now that both 32- and 64-bit Windows builds are supported, if a user tries to install the 64-bit version over the 32-bit version (or vice versa), they receive the following message:
e.g. ```Please uninstall Code 32bits before installing this 64bits version.```

I have updated this to improve the grammar and use a more industry-standard presentation of CPU/architecture:
e.g. ```Please uninstall the 32-bit version of Code before installing this 64-bit version.```

data.title: Ignore all sessions where Code was opened with a specific file by double-clicking in a file manager or from the command line with file paths
data.body:
Referring to this QA in issue 207 :
Q: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/207#issuecomment-318012379
A: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/207#issuecomment-321826340

**My request :**
When starting Code from its icon, or from the command line without file paths as argument : Restore the previous `window.restoreWindows` context, and ignore all sessions where Code was opened with a specific file by double-clicking in a file manager or from the command line with file paths.
Right now, those sessions are not ignored, and replace the last `window.restoreWindows` context.

Situation:
- VSCode Version:
```
Version 1.14.2
Commit cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e
Date 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
```
- OS Version:
```
"uname --all" output:
Linux ladyluck 4.12.3-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Jul 22 15:32:02 UTC 2017 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

- Reproduces without extensions: Yes

**Steps to Reproduce:**

```
Preferences: `"window.restoreWindows": "all"`
```
`window.restoreWindows` context :
```
One VSC window with a project folder opened. All files saved.
One VSC window with just a bunch of files opened. Some with unsaved changes.
Ctrl+Q to close all VSC windows and quit VSC.
```

1. **Reopening** VSC (as per the title of  issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/207) works as expected. Both windows are restored with all files.
2. Ctrl+Q again.
3. Then double-clicking a source file in the file manager, opens one VSC window with just the double-clicked file.
4. Ctrl+Q again.
5. Start VSC from its icon, and one window opened with just the one file (that was double-clicked from the file manager).
6. I restored the initial 2 windows with Ctrl+N, followed by Open recent.

At step 5, starting VSC from its icon, I had expected that would first open the 2 VSC windows. And that the source file (double clicked from the file manager) would be added to one of the 2 VSC windows. And that that window would be pushed to the foreground.
Similar to what happens now when there are already VSC windows opened, and you then double-click a source file from the file manager.

Adding the double-clicked file manager or command line file(s) to the 2 VSC windows is of course debatable. Some users might want a complete separation between whether Code was already started before the first file was double-clicked, and whether Code was still closed before the first double-click.

data.title: Slow to switch to/from tab with large collapsed section
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (dc3a6df693da5ad6e9219cb0269439cc6a8c401a, 2017-08-11T07:07:15.518Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. New empty directory
2. `npm install @types/lodash`
3. Create a file `a.ts` containing `_.add(1, 2)`
4. Go to definition on `_` to get taken to `node_modules/@types/lodash/index.d.ts`
5. Collapse the `declare namespace _` section, which spans nearly 20000 lines.
6. Go back to the tab from `a.ts`, then back to `index.d.ts`, repeat. It's noticeably slow. No issue if you uncollapse everything.

data.title: Indent rules don't work for some coding styles
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:09:15.006Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-83-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
you-complete-me|Ric|1.0.36
togglehs|bbe|0.1.2
chromium-codesearch|cha|0.0.7
vscode-instant-markdown|dba|1.2.1
python|don|0.7.0
gn|lju|0.0.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.2
difftomaster|pav|0.0.1
proto|pet|0.0.2
annotator|ryu|0.10.1
rewrap|stk|1.4.2
change-case|wma|1.0.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:


Write a function in C++ with parameters spread over 2 lines. The indent rules currently puts you 2 characters (or however many) in relative to the already indented second parameter line.

```
void Test(bool param1,
          bool param2) {
            ^ Indent rule puts you here
}

```
Instead, the indent rules should put you 2 characters in relative to the line where the function starts.

```
void Test(bool param1,
          bool param2) {
  ^ Indent should be here
}

```
This is extremely distracting, especially when pasting code from elsewhere.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

- OS Version: macOS 10.13 beta 4 (high sierra)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable `"zenMode.restore": true` in settings
2. Close editor, open it again
3. Check your file explorer, it will not expand

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No did not check

Whenever zenMode restore is enabled and you open vscode again, the file explorer in the side bar will not be expandable. Exiting zen mode and restarting vscode will show the file exporer and the files..

data.title: "Find in files" search shows incomplete results
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
language-x86-64-assembly|13x|2.2.11
project-manager|ale|0.19.0
githistory|don|0.2.3
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.2
csharp|ms-|1.12.0
copy-file-name|nem|1.0.0
markdown-checkbox|PKi|1.0.3
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.1.0
vscode-hexdump|sle|1.4.0
change-case|wma|1.0.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project and do a "find in files" search for anything valid. i.e. "foo"
2. Results should be incomplete, a file with the searched for string will not show in the results.
3. Manually open the file, either by going to symbol definition, or open file (Ctrl+P)
4. Do the same string search again
5. The string will be found in the newly open file now

The problem is I can't trust the search anymore, knowing that not all results are being returned.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Cannot store or use files stored on OneDrive or OneDrive for business and synced with the new Windows 10 Onedrive sync client in vscode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise Insider Preview, Version 1703, Build 16251.0

Steps to Reproduce:
Scenario save new file to OD or ODFB:
1. Create new file in vscode
2. Enter some code or random text
3. Save file to OneDrive or OneDrive for Business sync location
4. A system error occured

Scenario open file with script or code thats is saved on OD or ODFB:
1. Klik menu File > Open or Ctrl-O
2. Navigate to file location in OneDrive of OneDrive for Business sync location
3. Open file - File is empty
5. Open the same file in Notepad - File contains data

data.title: Paste indents twice with HTML formatting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:06.988Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- vscode-css-formatter|aes|0.0.2 vscode-intelephense-client|bme|0.7.2 githistory|don|0.2.3 python|don|0.7.0 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create an empty HTML tag. Example <div></div> 2. Go inside the tag and press enter. Assuming that you have 2 spaces indentation you get: ```
|
``` 3. Paste another HTML tag copied and you get pasted code indented twice. ```
This tag should be indented once but gets two.
``` Reproduces without extensions: Yes There are also another issue with indentation that looks similar: - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31255
